title: Make for the magic of Ireland’s Christmas marketsTravelandtourworld.com
text:
Make for the magic of Ireland’s Christmas markets Published on : Friday, October 9, 2015
Combining amazing shopping opportunities with the chance to sample the finest artisan food and drink, while soaking up the Irish yuletide atmosphere, these markets are fast-passes to a winter wonderland in cities, villages and towns across the country.
Here’s a round-up of the biggest and best:
Dazzling Dublin
In the capital, there’s a host of markets to choose from. But the big one is I Believe in Christmas, celebrating the magic of a traditional, authentic Irish Christmas village experience at the Custom House Quarter. The I Believe Christmas village will welcome Ireland’s first winter food, drink, craft and horticulture market in an exceptional setting. Graze your way through a fantastic array of local goodies and pick up some quality, one-off products from one of the 50 festive chalets.
The festival will be centred on what will be the country’s most iconic Christmas tree, standing at 50 foot tall, and in the spirit of Christmas giving to charity will play a focal part. High quality one-off gifts from individual traders, seasonal pop-up shops and iconic Irish design pieces will be on offer.
The market will run from 26 November right through to 23 December and reopen for the 30 December – 1 January period to ring in 2016 in style. With the best of Irish shopping, dining and entertainment in one location, this will be THE Christmas destination.
Crafty Cork
Or head further south to bask in the Glow, A Cork Christmas Celebration.The event includes a Food and Crafts Market featuring top class handmade bags, prints, mirrors, wood, jewellery, ceramic, textiles and print gifts. Santa sorted.
Across the road is the city’s famous English Market, one of the best covered market attractions in Europe, which will be festooned with festive food and drink.
Buzzing Belfast
Every year Belfast stages a lively Christmas Market in the grounds of its impressive city hall. The hugely popular market attracts traders from all around Europe and crowds of shoppers seeking distinctive gifts, gourmands gathering exotic foods and those just wanting to experience the buzz and warm their cockles with a hot chocolate or spicy mulled wine. This year it will run from 14 November – 20 December.
Nearby St Georges Market also promises terrific Christmas treats. One of the city’s oldest attractions, this historic and world-famous market will extend its opening hours to make it easier for you to pick up those special gifts, treats and stocking fillers. You might even bump into Santa.
Glorious Galway
The festive season in Ireland’s rugged west is a blend of brooding skies and chill winds, but the gaiety and warmth of Christmas in Galway will dispel the dark nights of winter. Eyre Square is set to host a Christmas wonderland, and the Spanish Arch area will be home to vintage carousels and amusements. Christmas on Ice will also be there, alongside Christmas pantomimes, literary trails and craft and artisan markets. Glorious.
Victorian Derry~Londonderry
Christmas in the famous Walled City takes on a Victorian theme this year with a weekend of activities and events in and around the majestic Guildhall in the heart of the city. Including a craft fair featuring 40 local crafters, the celebrations add to the many reasons for visiting this ancient and exuberant city, which was the UK’s first City of Culture.
The Sound of Light Christmas Carnival will be another highlight to compliment the city’s Christmas shopping experience. Audiences will be invited to follow the Sound of Light Trail through the historic quarters of the old city in a journey of reflection, joy, wonder and celebration.
